questions.text: An ultrasound of a 28-year-old woman with monochorionic-diamniotic twins reveals a significant difference in amniotic fluid levels between the two sacs. Twin A has polyhydramnios, while Twin B has oligohydramnios. Which of the following symptoms would NOT be found in Twin A?

options.label: A
options.text: Elevated blood pressure

options.label: B
options.text: Increased red blood cell count

options.label: C
options.text: Reduced blood volume

options.label: D
options.text: Enlarged heart

questions.explanation:
Recipient twin

Donor twin
  • Polyhydramnios
  • Polycythemia
  • Hypertension
  • Hypervolemia
  • Increased risk of congestive heart failure and hydrops
  • Oligohydramnios
  • Anemia
  • Hypotension
  • Hypovolemia

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman, gravida 2 para 1, presents to your clinic at 20 weeks of gestation for a routine prenatal visit. She mentions increased fatigue, shortness of breath, and noticeable swelling in her legs and feet. On examination, her blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg, and there is no proteinuria. A recent ultrasound confirmed a dichorionic diamniotic twin pregnancy. Which of the following physiological changes is most likely responsible for her symptoms?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased cardiac output

options.label: B
options.text: Increased peripheral vascular resistance

options.label: C
options.text: Decreased blood volume

options.label: D
options.text: Reduced glomerular filtration rate

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravida at 38 weeks of gestation presents to the labor and delivery unit in active labor. She is carrying dichorionic diamniotic twins. The first twin is in a cephalic presentation and delivers vaginally without complications. After the delivery of the first twin, the second twin is found to be in a transverse lie. Given the situation, the decision is made to perform an internal podalic version. Which of the following statements is true regarding internal podalic version in the context of twin pregnancy?

options.label: A
options.text: It is necessary if the second twin is in a breech presentation.

options.label: B
options.text: It involves converting the second twin to a cephalic presentation externally.

options.label: C
options.text: It is performed by reaching into the uterus to grasp and bring down the feet of the second twin for a breech delivery.

options.label: D
options.text: It is contraindicated in all cases of transverse lie for the second twin.

questions.correct_answer: C. It is performed by reaching into the uterus to grasp and bring down the feet of the second twin for a breech delivery.

questions.text: A 32-year-old pregnant woman at 36 weeks gestation comes for her routine prenatal visit. She is expecting twins, and this is her first pregnancy. An ultrasound performed today shows that the first twin (Twin A) is in a cephalic presentation, while the second twin (Twin B) is in a breech presentation. Both fetuses have normal growth parameters and amniotic fluid indices, and there are no signs of fetal distress. The patient has no significant medical or obstetric history. What is the most appropriate mode of delivery for this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Planned Cesarean section for both twins

options.label: B
options.text: Vaginal delivery for both twins, with a possible need for breech extraction for Twin B

options.label: C
options.text: Vaginal delivery for Twin A followed by an immediate Cesarean section for Twin B

options.label: D
options.text: External cephalic version for Twin B followed by a planned vaginal delivery for both twins

questions.correct_answer: B. Vaginal delivery for both twins, with a possible need for breech extraction for Twin B

questions.text: A 32-year-old pregnant woman is undergoing her routine prenatal ultrasound at 18 weeks gestation. The ultrasound reveals she is carrying twins. Further assessment confirms that the twins share a single amniotic sac and a single fused placenta. Which of the following complications is most specific to this type of twin pregnancy?

options.label: A
options.text: Twin-Twin Transfusion Syndrome (TTTS)

options.label: B
options.text: Cord entanglement

options.label: C
options.text: Selective intrauterine growth restriction (sIUGR)

options.label: D
options.text: Preterm labor

questions.text: Which of the following is not a correct statement with respect to selective intrauterine growth restriction (sIUGR)?

options.label: A
options.text: The fetal weight of one twin is less than the 10th percentile for normal fetuses.

options.label: B
options.text: There is a difference in weight of ≥25% between the twins.

options.label: C
options.text: Both twins have an unequal share of the placental mass.

options.label: D
options.text: MCA Doppler is used as the main modality of diagnosis in sIUGR.

questions.correct_answer: D. MCA Doppler is used as the main modality of diagnosis in sIUGR.

questions.text: Identify the diagnosis related to the image:

options.label: A
options.text: Twin-to-Twin Transfusion Syndrome (TTTS)

options.label: B
options.text: Twin Reversed Arterial Perfusion (TRAP) Sequence

options.label: C
options.text: Twin Anemia Polycythemia Sequence (TAPS)

options.label: D
options.text: Intrauterine Growth Restriction (IUGR)

questions.correct_answer: B. Twin Reversed Arterial Perfusion (TRAP) Sequence

questions.text: A 29-year-old pregnant woman with monochorionic diamniotic twins visits for a routine ultrasound at 32 weeks gestation. There is no significant difference in the weight or amniotic fluid volumes of the twins. Doppler studies show a significant difference in the middle cerebral artery peak systolic velocity (MCA PSV) between the twins. What is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Twin-to-Twin Transfusion Syndrome (TTTS)

options.label: B
options.text: Twin Reversed Arterial Perfusion (TRAP) Sequence

options.label: C
options.text: Twin Anemia Polycythemia Sequence (TAPS)

options.label: D
options.text: ntrauterine Growth Restriction (IUGR)

questions.text: All of the following can be management options for complicated cases of TTTS except?

options.label: A
options.text: Laser ablation of deep arteriovenous anastomosis

options.label: B
options.text: Amnioreduction in the recipient twin

options.label: C
options.text: Single fetal reduction of the recipient twin

options.label: D
options.text: Septostomy

questions.correct_answer: C. Single fetal reduction of the recipient twin
questions.explanation:
Definition
  • TTTS is characterized by deep AV anastomosis between monochorionic twins.
  • More common in MCDA>MCMA

Clinical Findings
  • Donor Twin: Oligohydramnios (<2 cm), anemia, hypovolemia, hypotension, growth restriction, "stuck" appearance.
  • Recipient Twin: Polyhydramnios (>8 cm), polycythemia, hypervolemia, hypertension, larger size, risk of heart failure and hydrops fetalis.

Diagnostic Criteria
  • Ultrasound Findings: MCDA twin pregnancy, discrepant amniotic fluid volumes, size discrepancy.
  • Doppler Studies: Abnormal blood flow patterns, such as absent or reversed end-diastolic flow in the donor twin's umbilical artery.
  • Hematologic Findings: Hemoglobin difference >5 g%, estimated fetal weight discrepancy >25%.

Management

(Option A,B and D ruled out)
  • Laser Ablation
  • Amnioreduction
  • Septostomy
  • Selective Reduction of donor twin

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describes the Quintero staging system for Twin-to-Twin Transfusion Syndrome (TTTS)?

options.label: A
options.text: Stage I is characterized by absent or reversed end-diastolic flow in the umbilical artery of the donor twin.

options.label: B
options.text: Stage II is defined by the presence of polyhydramnios in the recipient twin and anhydramnios in the donor twin.

options.label: C
options.text: Stage III involves critically abnormal Doppler findings in one or both twins.

options.label: D
options.text: Stage V indicates the presence of hydrops fetalis in one or both twins.

questions.correct_answer: C. Stage III involves critically abnormal Doppler findings in one or both twins.
questions.explanation:
Stage

Description

Stage I (Option A ruled out)

Polyhydramnios in the recipient twin (deepest vertical pocket ≥8 cm) and oligohydramnios in the donor twin (deepest vertical pocket ≤2 cm), with a visible bladder in the donor twin.

Stage II (Option B ruled out)

The donor twin's bladder is not visible on ultrasound, indicating severe oligohydramnios.

Stage III

Critically abnormal Doppler findings, such as absent or reversed end-diastolic flow in the umbilical artery, reversed flow in the ductus venosus, or pulsatile flow in the umbilical vein in one or both twins

Stage IV

Presence of hydrops fetalis in one or both twins, indicating severe fetal compromise

Stage V (Option D ruled out)

Demise of one or both twins

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding multifetal pregnancy, except:

options.label: A
options.text: Hellin's rule states that the incidence of twins is approximately 1 in 80 pregnancies.

options.label: B
options.text: Advanced maternal age increases the likelihood of multifetal pregnancy.

options.label: C
options.text: The use of fertility treatments can elevate the risk of multifetal pregnancy.

options.label: D
options.text: Multifetal pregnancies are associated with decreased risk of preterm birth.

questions.correct_answer: D. Multifetal pregnancies are associated with decreased risk of preterm birth.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman pregnant with monochorionic-diamniotic twins presents for a routine ultrasound. The ultrasound reveals no cardiac activity in one of the twins. The other twin has normal cardiac activity. Which of the following is a major complication in the surviving twin?

options.label: A
options.text: Oligohydramnios

options.label: B
options.text: Cerebral palsy

options.label: C
options.text: Anemia

options.label: D
options.text: Hypotension

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with a history of inability to conceive , presents at 12 weeks gestation following her first IVF cycle. Ultrasound confirms a quadruplet pregnancy. The doctor discusses multifetal reduction. Which of the following statements regarding fetal reduction is FALSE?

options.label: A
options.text: Improves the overall perinatal outcome in quadruplets

options.label: B
options.text: Potassium chloride is used in fetal reduction

options.label: C
options.text: Performed between 11 and 13 weeks of gestation

options.label: D
options.text: Monochorionic twin pregnancies are ideally suited for fetal reduction procedures

questions.correct_answer: D. Monochorionic twin pregnancies are ideally suited for fetal reduction procedures

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true?

options.label: A
options.text: Some degree of discordant growth is normal in dizygotic twins

options.label: B
options.text: Intrauterine death of one fetus is more in dizygotic twins

options.label: C
options.text: Fetal anomalies are more commonly seen in dizygotic twins

options.label: D
options.text: Fetal complications in multifetal pregnancy doesn't depend on chorionicity

questions.correct_answer: A. Some degree of discordant growth is normal in dizygotic twins
questions.explanation:
Foetal Complications in Multifetal Pregnancies

Increased Miscarriage Rate

More common in monozygotic twins.

High Premature Birth Rate

80% occurrence, with associated risks.

Discordant Twin Growth
  • 20% prevalence, with pathological discordance (≥25% weight difference).
  • Causes: Twin-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS), placental insufficiency, intrauterine growth restriction, structural anomalies.

Increased Intrauterine Foetal Death
  • More common in monozygotic twins. (Option B ruled out)
  • First Trimester: Vanishing twin through resorption.
  • Second Trimester: Fetus papyraceous (mummified foetus).
  • Late Pregnancy: Risks to surviving twin or maternal disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).

Appearing Twin Phenomenon

A twin initially missed on ultrasound but detected later, more common in monozygotic twins.

Increased Foetal Anomalies
  • 2-4% higher risk in monozygous twins than in singleton pregnancies. (Option C ruled out)
  • Includes anencephaly, holoprosencephaly, neural tube defects, symmelia, microcephaly, cardiac anomalies and Down’s syndrome.

Higher Risk of Asphyxia and Stillbirth
  • Increased risk due to pre-eclampsia, malpresentation, placental abruption, and operative interventions.
  • The second twin is at higher risk.

Specific Complications in Monozygotic/Monochorionic Twins:

Twin-Twin Transfusion Syndrome (TTTS)

Occurs in 10-15% of monozygotic twins due to placental vascular anastomosis.

Dead Foetus Syndrome

2-7% occurrence, with a 25% risk of poor outcomes for the surviving twin.

Twin Reversed Arterial Perfusion (TRAP)

High risk of perinatal death from cardiac failure in the healthy twin; chromosomal abnormalities in the perfused twin.

Monoamniotic Twins

High perinatal mortality due to cord entanglement, low birth weight and congenital anomalies.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman at 28 weeks gestation, conceived via in vitro fertilization (IVF) is now carrying dichorionic-diamniotic twins. She reports increasing discomfort and shortness of breath over the past few weeks. Fetal heart rates are within normal limits. Which of the following is the least likely complication in her pregnancy ?

options.label: A
options.text: Twin to Twin Transfusion Syndrome

options.label: B
options.text: Preterm labor

options.label: C
options.text: Pre-eclampsia

options.label: D
options.text: Malpresentation

questions.correct_answer: A. Twin to Twin Transfusion Syndrome
questions.explanation:
Pregnancy

Labor

Puerperium
  • Nausea, vomiting
  • Anemia
  • PIH and pre-eclampsia
  • Polyhydramnios/ oligohydramnios
  • Preterm labor
  • Malpresentation
  • Antepartum hemorrhage
  • Mechanical distress (dyspnea, palpitation)
  • Prolonged labor
  • Operative interference
  • Postpartum hemorrhage
  • Subinvolution
  • Infection
  • Lactation failure

questions.text: During a chorionicity scan in a twin pregnancy, which imaging finding would indicate Monochorionic-Monoamniotic (MCMA) twins?

options.label: A
options.text: Visualization of two distinct placentas and separate amniotic sacs

options.label: B
options.text: Detection of a single placenta and two separate amniotic sacs

options.label: C
options.text: Identification of a single placenta and a single shared amniotic sac

options.label: D
options.text: Observation of two placentas and a single shared amniotic sac

questions.correct_answer: C. Identification of a single placenta and a single shared amniotic sac

questions.text: Which of the following statements correctly differentiates between Dichorionic-Diamniotic (DCDA), Monochorionic-Diamniotic (MCDA), and Monochorionic-Monoamniotic (MCMA) twins?

options.label: A
options.text: DCDA twins each have their own chorion and amnion, while MCDA twins share a chorion but have separate amniotic sacs, and MCMA twins share both a chorion and an amnion.

options.label: B
options.text: DCDA twins share a chorion and an amnion, MCDA twins each have their own chorion but share an amnion, and MCMA twins have separate chorions and amniotic sacs.

options.label: C
options.text: MCDA twins have separate placentas and amniotic sacs, DCDA twins share a chorion but have separate amniotic sacs, and MCMA twins share both chorion and amnion.

options.label: D
options.text: MCMA twins share a chorion but have separate amniotic sacs, DCDA twins each have their own chorion and amnion, and MCDA twins share both chorion and amnion.

questions.correct_answer: A. DCDA twins each have their own chorion and amnion, while MCDA twins share a chorion but have separate amniotic sacs, and MCMA twins share both a chorion and an amnion.
questions.explanation:
Timing of Cleavage

Placenta & Membrane Status

< 72 hours

Dichorionic-Diamniotic twins each have their own separate placenta and amniotic sac.

Days 4–7

Monochorionic-Diamniotic twins share one placenta (chorion) but have separate amniotic sacs.

Days 8–12

Monochorionic-Monoamniotic twins share both the placenta and the amniotic sac.

questions.text: Which type of monozygotic twins develops when the zygote splits very early, usually within the first 3 days after fertilization, resulting in separate placentas and amniotic sacs for each twin?

options.label: A
options.text: Monochorionic-diamniotic twins

options.label: B
options.text: Monochorionic-monoamniotic twins

options.label: C
options.text: Dichorionic-diamniotic twins

options.label: D
options.text: Conjoined twins

questions.explanation:
Zygosity

Chorionicity

Zygosity refers to the genetic makeup of twin pregnancies. Monozygotic twins originate from a single fertilized egg that splits into two, leading to genetically identical individuals.

Chorionicity refers to the placenta’s membrane status. Chorionicity is determined by the timing of embryo division.

Timing of Cleavage

Placenta & Membrane Status

< 72 hours

(Option C)

Dichorionic-Diamniotic twins each have their own separate placenta and amniotic sac.

Days 4–7

(Option A)

Monochorionic-Diamniotic twins share one placenta (chorion) but have separate amniotic sacs.

Days 8–12

(Option B)

Monochorionic-Monoamniotic twins share both the placenta and the amniotic sac.

Day > 13

(Option D)

Conjoined (Siamese) are physically connected and may share organs or tissues, resulting from a very late and incomplete split.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes superfetation in the context of twin formation?

options.label: A
options.text: The fertilization of two ova released during the same menstrual cycle, possibly resulting in twins of the same gestational age but different fathers.

options.label: B
options.text: The occurrence of a second pregnancy while already carrying a fetus, leading to twins of different gestational ages.

options.label: C
options.text: The fertilization of a single ovum by two different sperm cells, resulting in a rare form of identical twins.

options.label: D
options.text: The splitting of a single fertilized egg into two embryos, leading to identical twins of the same gestational age.

questions.correct_answer: B. The occurrence of a second pregnancy while already carrying a fetus, leading to twins of different gestational ages.
